results.title: John Lethbridge
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions, National Gallery of Victoria, Bob Weis, Judi Stack and Robert Lindsay
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
John Lethbridge’s works, his paintings, drawings and sculptural installations develop out of a personal necessity to try to give an order to the rituals and repeating experiences of life that recur in an apparently unordered and random world. His recent work can be described as “Post Conceptual Romanticism”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Open Channel Productions, National Gallery of Victoria, Bob Weis, Judi Stack and Robert Lindsay

results.title: John Lee Hooker: that's my story
results.brief_description: This documentary traces the life and times of famous Afro-American blues musician John Lee Hooker. Born in the heart of the Mississippi Delta Hooker went on to become a famous, influential and highly respected player. Made for television this documentary features interviews with many of Hooker’s music peers, including Carlos Santana, Eric Clapton, Bonnie Rait, Edie Kirkland and Robert Cray. Various artists discuss the influence of Hooker on their music and the remarkable life and times of this great artist. Family and friends discuss the cultural influence of Hooker and the effect that he had on them personally. Features a current interview with Hooker as well as archival footage of him playing in the 1950s. Songs include Dimples, Maudie, I’m in the mood, Crawlin’ Kingsnake, This is hip and Boogie chillin. John Lee Hooker died in 2001, at the age of 83.

results.title: John Law and the Mississippi bubble
results.creator_credit: National Arts Board of Canada, Jerry Krepakevich and Richard Coombe
results.brief_description: It was one of the most sensational get-rich-quick schemes heard of in a long time, but it eventually burst over the head of its originator, John Law. This “rags to riches to rags” story, in which the plan was to open a bank and exchange banknotes (paper!) for gold at wildly inflated share prices, ends when John Law, having been cleaned out as a result of a rush to cash in the notes, is left broke and broken-hearted. Animated by Richard Condie, Sharon Condie, Gordon Manson. Music by Patrick Godfrey. Sound by Bill Eakin and Ken Page. Voice and Narration by Stanley Jackson. (Award: Tampare)

results.title: John Keats: poet
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Written by Archibald MacLeish, this film dramatizes the life of Keats from his early years in England until his death in Rome at the age of 26. Relating the tragedies in his personal life to his development as a poet, the film portrays Keat’s reactions to deaths in his family, financial worries, brutal criticism to his poetry, a troubled love affair, and the failing health that Keats endured, and rose above in his exceeding devotion to his art. Excerpts from his letters and poetry reveal the integrity of the man and the genius of the poet. Narrated by James Mason.

results.title: John Howard is a happening
results.brief_description: Ann Tobin narrates this documentary of a day in the life of John Banda, a boy who lives in the John Howard squatter settlement.

results.title: John Grierson
results.brief_description: John Grierson’s address on the occasion of the “Thirty Years of the British Documentary” season at the National Film Theatre, London, in August 1959. He outlines the basic intentions of the early documentary filmmakers and the influence which British documentary has since had on the rest of the world.

results.title: John Dowie: sculptor
results.creator_credit: Film Partnership (Vic.), Alcoa Australia and Graham Bye
results.brief_description: Narrated by the sculptor, the film shows a number of works by John Dowie. The Adelaide-born sculptor uses plaster, stone, bronze and aluminium as mediums for his works. Various sculptures around Adelaide are featured; the wall reliefs in the Library of the South Australian Institute of Technology and the fountain at Victoria Square amongst them.

results.title: John Carpenter's Vampires
results.creator_credit: Largo Entertainment, Sandy King and John Carpenter
results.brief_description: Mainly working within the parameters of the horror genre, few director’s have the popularity and cult status to warrant their name in the films title, however John Carpenter (“Halloween”, “The Thing”, “Escape from New York”, “Assault on Precinct 13”) has the body of work and the loyal followers to back it up. Based on John Steakley’s novel, “Vampires” stars James Woods as Jack Crow, a sadistic vampire slayer working for the Vatican and searching for the 600 year old originator of the blood curse. Crow and his crew of vampire hunters end up in a small town in New Mexico where they uncover a ‘nest’ of the undead. As bait they use a newly bitten prostitute (Sheryl Lee) who now has telepathic links to the master, in an effort to trap the head bloodsucker. Cast also includes Daniel Baldwin, Thomas Ian Griffith, Maximillian Schell, and Tim Guinee. Music by John Carpenter.

results.title: John Canemaker: marching to a different toon [DVD]
results.brief_description: John Canemaker is a well-regarded American animator who works in a variety of styles and has always succeeded in plumbing an array of emotions and situations in a humorous and engaging manner. Canemaker is also an esteemed animation historian and biographer. His fluid style, hand drawn and quite low-tech, is unpredictable and highly entertaining, cleverly evolving from one moment to the next. “Confessions of a star dreamer”: An actress and vamp discusses her feelings toward procreating, her craft and the industry. “Bridgehampton”: With music by Fred Hersch, this piece elegantly portrays a suburban changing of the seasons. “Confessions of a stand-up”: Wonderful piece satirising the pitfalls and pratfalls of being a comedian, as told by Dennis Blair. “Bottom’s dream”: Canemaker reworks the notions underpinning Shakespearean comical character, Bottom. “The Wizard’s son”: The young son of a wizard imagines the possibilities and adventures that await him, wreaking havoc in the meantime. “Behind the scenes”: An absurd piece on the interaction between line, form and shape. Bonus material includes excerpts from: “The Creative spirit” with a commentary about creative thought and processes; “Laughter is good medicine”; “Break the silence: kids against child abuse”; “What do children think when they think of the bomb”; “Science experiences”; and three thirty second advertisements for AIDS benefits.
